column4: I'm trying to get ubuntu to work on my box, I've installed everything, and then it fails to start the X-server. Specifically it gives an error VESA(0): No matching modes, Screen(s) found, but none have a usable configuration. I've searched online, and it looks like this was a bug report filed with a previous version (I've done a dist-upgrade from FF). I'm out of ideas on how to resolve this issue... Any clues?
i would run this command sudo dpkg-reconfigure xserver-xorg  and take generic defaults for everything(use Vesa for video, not ati/nvidia), then once you get a GUI, work on fixing everything right.
you'll have to do that in safe mode(one of your grub menu entries)
Yeah, I would think that this would work as well, and I don't think it's a hardware failure since the device has previously worked...

I've already tried to reconfigure x. I've looked up the refresh rates and other monitor specs on the web, and I've filled those values in. I'm editing the xorg.conf manually, so safe mode is not necessary (?)
ok, i would just do everything generic, and see if you can get X to start.
do everything generic, and you will likely get everything to start.
so I tried that as well, and I couldn't get anything... is this a known issue or something? The bug report that I found indicates that is was resolved?
no, onlyu thing i know, is you're doing something wrong.. what did you choose when it asked for your video device?
video device was chosen as vesa since I don't have a video card in here anyways
you're doing something jacked up,c uz if you use generic defaults, X should start, barring some other hardware problem
oh, and the monitor is a Sceptre X7-Agama. The default is not correct, so I set the horizontal refresh rate to the correct value, and still no X...
sigh.. you just don't get it... i give up
I've already tried the defaults, and set it to vesa with no luck... What am I not getting?
nothing... good luck with it.
very wierd...
i'd have never thought that, so you're using an onboard device now, right?

Well, yeah. There's on-board video which I guess I'm using now, and then there's this HDMI card that comes with the motherboard (it's not a regular card, it has a feed directly off the motherboard as well as PCI). I'm thinking this non-normal setup is what's causing linux to get confuzzled
sounds it.
I don't want to rub it in, but as you can see, I actually wasn't doing anything wrong :) Don't be so quick to assume
lol
